questions.text: For measurement of non-invasive blood pressure, cuff width influences the blood pressure reading. Match the columns in the table in relevance to the given figure regarding the same.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Blood pressure cuff width influences the pressure readings. The narrowest cuff (A) will require more pressure, and the widest cuff (C) less pressure, to occlude the brachial artery for determination of systolic pressure.

  • Too narrow a cuff may produce a large overestimation (false high) of systolic pressure, requiring more pressure to produce the same amount of occlusion.
  • A wider cuff may underestimate the systolic pressure (false low), requiring less pressure for the same amount of occlusion.
  • The cuff's bladder should extend at least halfway around the extremity, and the width of the cuff should be 20% to 50% greater than the diameter of the extremity.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman is having a bunionectomy. You perform an ankle block using the landmark technique. Which of the following nerves could a nerve stimulator help locate the nerve to block?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • As the tibial nerve is the only one with a motor component beyond the block site, it is the only nerve that a nerve stimulator may identify.
  • An ankle block may be performed to provide analgesia or anaesthesia for forefoot operations.
  • It requires blockade of the deep and superficial peroneal nerves, sural nerve, saphenous nerve and tibial nerve.
  • A nerve stimulator is a device that sends electrical signals through a needle to stimulate nerves and elicit muscle response, and helps locate the nerve to block.
  • This helps confirm the needle is near the nerve and not accidentally stimulating other tissues.

Ankle block technique:

questions.text: During a complex mitral valve replacement, it is determined that the patient will benefit from brief protective hypothermia. Of the options listed below, core temperature is best measured via the?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Numerous sites can be used to monitor temperature in the operating room.
  • The tympanic membrane theoretically reflects brain temperaturebecause the auditory canal's blood supply is the external carotid artery.
  • Tympanic membrane temperatures reflect core body temperature.
  • Nasopharyngeal temperature measurement is a reliable method for assessing core body temperature, particularly in clinical settings such as anaesthesia and intensive care. This technique offers a minimally invasive alternative to traditional methods like rectal or oesophageal temperature monitoring.
  • According to ASA, in all patients under GA and neuraxial (RA), if the procedure is more than 30 minutes, temperature monitoring is mandatory.

Sites for core temperature monitoring according to guidelines:

  • Pulmonary artery catheter.
  • lower 1/3rd of esophagus(most common).
  • Tympanic membrane.
  • Rectal
  • Nasopharynx

Explanation of other options:

Bladder (Option B): After tympanic membrane (perfused by carotid artery) and pulmonary artery measurements, the best reflector of core temperature is bladder temperature. The bladder temperature is dependent on the flow of urine, and high flows are necessary to ensure accurate measurement of core temperature.

Axilla (Option C): Axillary and skin temperatures are highly prone to errors. Depending on skin perfusion, there is a variable correlation between axillary temperature and core temperature.

Rectum (Option D): Rectal temperature is a poor substitute, and a probe can induce trauma; tympanic membrane is chosen over this as it is non-invasive. Rectal temperature probes have a slow response to changes in core temperature and may be influenced by perfusion changes or stool.

questions.text:
Match the following capnographs accordingly.?




1: Normal capnograph
2: Patient's spontaneous breath
3: Bronchospasm
4: Oesophageal intubation
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A Capnometer is simply a device that measures CO2 concentration.
  • It is a device that records and displays CO2 concentrations, usually as a function of time.
  • A Capnograph refers to the graphic displays that the capnometer generates.
  • The figure shows the representative time capnograph for three breaths.
    • The inspiratory segment is referred to as phase 0 in this figure.
    • The expiratory segment is divided into phases I, II, III, and IV.
    • α denotes the angle between phases II and III, whereas β denotes the angle between phase III and the descending limb of phase 0.
    • Phase IV (dashed line in third breath) denotes the upstroke observed at the end of phase III in some patients.
  • Patient's spontaneous breath (Image A): Clefts during phase III of the capnography trace indicate spontaneous breathing efforts during controlled mechanical ventilation, also called curare clefts.
  • Bronchospasm (Image C): increased upslope of phase III, as may occur during bronchospasm (asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease), or a partially obstructed endotracheal tube/breathing circuit.
  • Oesophagal intubation (Image B): The graph of end tracheal CO2 exhaled gradually decreases.

questions.text: Capnography can help detect all of the following promptly, except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • It is important to remember that capnography will show a normal capnograph and end-tidal CO2 immediately following endobronchial intubation.
  • Anaesthesia providers must be vigilant to always listen for bilateral breath sounds and observe bilateral chest rise to confirm tracheal intubation.

Risks of Endobronchial Intubation:

  • Results in collapse (atelectasis) of the non-ventilated lung, leading to hypoxaemia, hypercapnia, and potential barotrauma (pneumothorax)
  • Often affects the right lung due to anatomy; a right mainstem ETT may even obstruct the right upper lobe.
  • May be mistaken for pneumothorax, resulting in unnecessary chest drain insertion
  • Trauma to the bronchial mucosa with deliberate techniques or prolonged malposition.

Explanation of other opinions:

Oesophagal intubation (Option B): Will show progressive decrease of etCO2 with breaths.

Bronchospasm(Option C): will show a steep upslope of the trace

Pulmonary embolism(Option D): A Sudden decrease in etCO2 is seen in pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: You see the following feature on the ECG of a patient intraoperatively. Which electrolyte imbalance should you suspect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Potassium plays a vital role in maintaining the resting membrane potential and the action potential of cardiac cells.
  • Elevated extracellular potassium reduces the transmembrane potassium gradient, leading to partial depolarisation of myocardial cells.
  • This depolarisation affects various ion channels, notably the voltage-gated sodium channels (NaV1.5), which are essential for initiating and conducting action potentials.
  • Hyperkalemia leads to tall T waves on the ECG.
  • The earliest change in the ECG is the appearance of a tall and tapering ( tented) T wave that is most evident in the precordial leads V2 and V3.

ECG changes according to the range of Hyperkalemia:

  • Mild Hyperkalemia (5.5-6.5 mmol/L):
    • Partial depolarisation accelerates repolarisation, resulting in tall, peaked T waves on the ECG.
    • This is due to synchronous early repolarisation of a large myocardial mass.
  • Moderate Hyperkalemia (6.5-7.5 mmol/L):
    • Further depolarisation leads to inactivation of NaV1.5 channels, reducing conduction velocity.
    • This manifests as prolonged PR intervals and QRS complexes, and the P wave may flatten or disappear r
  • Severe Hyperkalemia (>7.5 mmol/L):
    • Extensive depolarisation can cause complete inactivation of NaV1.5 channels, leading to a significant decrease in conduction velocity.
    • The QRS complex may widen and merge with the T wave, forming a sine wave pattern, a pre-terminal rhythm associated with impending asystole.

The following image shows progressive ECG changes due to hyperkalemia.

Explanation of other options:

Option (A): Hypokalemia mainly causes prolongation of the QT interval.

Option (C) and (D): ECG changes associated with hyponatremia and hypernatremia are often subtle and nonspecific.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9364480/

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with shortness of breath and weakness. A 12-lead electrocardiogram shows a rate of 42 beats per minute with complete dissociation of P waves from QRS complexes. What is the most likely jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform that will be seen?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • In the above case, there is complete dissociation of P waves from QRS complex that suggests AV dissociation and Heart block.
  • Cannon A waves are caused by atrial contraction against a closed tricuspid valve, such as in complete heart block.
  • JVP - Pressure of the venous column of blood in the Right Internal Jugular Vein.

Different waves in JVP:

  • A wave produced by right atrial contraction.
  • The C wave is produced during the ventricular systole.
  • X wave represents the fall in right atrial pressure after a wave peak.
  • The wave represents venous return to the right column.
  • Y descent represents the opening of the tricuspid valve.
  • Elevated JVP(>4 cm above the sternal angle) with normal waveforms may reflect right heart failure and fluid overload.
  • Elevated JVPwith absent waveforms may be caused by superior vena cava obstruction.
  • Elevated JVP with deep x and y descentsmay be seen with constrictive pericarditis.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Absent JVP(Option A): may be present in patients who are intravascularly depleted

Absent a waves(Option B): may be seen in atrial fibrillation

Large v waves(Option C) are a feature of tricuspid regurgitation

choices.text: Prone to water precipitation in the aspiration tube
The Weight of the sensor can cause traction on the tracheal tube

questions.text: Which of the following is not a disadvantage of the given type of capnography monitoring?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • Capnography can be of two types: Mainstream (non-diverting) and side-stream capnography.
  • The given image is that of a non-diverting (mainstream) capnograph. It measures CO2passing through an adaptor placed in the breathing circuit. Infrared light transmission through the gas is measured, and the CO2 concentration on End-tidal CO2 is shown.
  • Infrared transducers are determined by the monitor.
  • The disadvantages of a non-diverting capnograph are:
    • Incapable of detecting inspired CO2(Option A ruled out).
    • The weight of the sensor causes traction on the tracheal tube(Option C ruled out).
    • The generation of radiant heat can cause skin burns(Option D ruled out)

Option B is the disadvantage of diverting the capnograph and not that of a non-diverting capnograph.

  • Diverting (side stream) capnographs continuously suction gas from the breathing circuit into a sample cell within the bedside monitor.
  • Diverting units are prone to water precipitation in the aspiration tube and sampling cell, which can obstruct the sampling line and erroneous readings.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are false.
The Assertion is true, but the reason is false.
Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is correct for assertion.
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is not correct for assertion

questions.text:
Choose the correct option for the given statements:
Assertion: Some muscles reflect respiratory muscle response better than others
Reason: All muscle groups demonstrate equal sensitivities to muscle relaxants.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • When monitoring neuromuscular blockade, it is important to realise that different muscle groups demonstrate different sensitivities to muscle relaxants.
  • Some muscles reflect respiratory muscle response better than others
  • For example, the onset of neuromuscular blockade in central muscles such as the diaphragm is faster than that in peripheral muscles such as the adductor pollicis. For example, Neuromuscular block has a shorter duration and faster recovery in the laryngeal muscles in comparison to the adductor pollicis.

Explanation of the relevant topic:

Neuromuscular blockade monitoring:

a.Train-of-Four (TOF) Stimulation:

  • Delivers 4 pulses at 2 Hz (one every 0.5 s) to evaluate the depth of blockade
  • TOF count (TOFC): Number of twitches seen (0-4).
    • 0 = full block
    • 1-3 = moderate block
    • 4 = recovery phase (though may still have fade)
  • TOF ratio (TOFR): Amplitude of 4th twitch divided by 1st twitch (T4/T1). TOFR ≥ 0.9 is required for safe extubation
  • Interpretation:
    • Unparalyzed: TOFC = 4, TOFR ≈1
    • Non-depolarising block: fade present, TOFR < 1
    • Recovery threshold: TOFR ≥ 0.9 (quantitative)

b.Post-Tetanic Count (PTC).

c.Double-Burst Stimulation (DBS).

d.Single Twitch & Tetanic Stimuli.

Muscle Response Sites:

  • Adductor pollicis (ulnar nerve/wrist): Preferred site-recovery here correlates well with airway and pharyngeal muscle function.
  • Orbicularis oculi/corrugator supercilii: Recover earlier (diaphragm-like); risk of overestimating neuromuscular recovery if used alone

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10223480/

choices.text: The Red box is known as post-tetanic potentiation
Post tetanic count >5 indicates profound neuromuscular blockade
Post tetanic count of >15 is equivalent to two twitches in TOF
Post-tetanic potentiation is seen in the presence of a non-depolarising agent

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct about the following image except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Intense muscle blockade can completely abolish the response to a train of four.
  • Tetanic stimulation increases the mobilisation of ACh in the presynaptic membrane.
  • Option A: Subsequent electrical stimulation uses twitches at 1-second intervals, releasing supra-normal concentrations of ACh sufficient to overcome the effect of non-depolarising relaxants. This is called post-tetanic potentiation.
  • Post-tetanic potentiation refers to the transient increase in muscle response following a tetanic stimulus, observed during deep neuromuscular blockade. This phenomenon is utilised to assess the depth of blockade when standard monitoring methods like Train-of-Four (TOF) are not effective.
  • Option B: PTC >5 indicates neuromuscular blockade is not profound. Hence, option B is wrong in the above question.
  • Option C: A PTC > 15 is at least equivalent to two twitches of a TOF, and at this level, successful pharmacological reversal of the remaining muscle blockade is possible.
  • Option D: Post-tetanic potentiation is seen in the presence of a non-depolarising agent and phase II block with succinylcholine. It occurs due to a transient increase in acetylcholine release following tetanic stimulation.

Reference:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov

questions.text: Approximately 30 minutes after the induction of general anaesthesia in a healthy adult patient, you notice that core body temperature has dropped by a full degree Celsius. This is most likely due to
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • On average, core temperature declines by approximately 1 to 1.5°C after the induction of general anaesthesia.
  • This initial drop in core body temperature is primarily due to redistribution (core to periphery) from the vasodilation properties of many anaesthetics.
  • The initial rapid drop of heat is due to redistribution and is followed by a slower drop due to a decrease in basal metabolic rate and d drop due to convection, conduction and radiation. (Option A, B, and D ruled out)

questions.text: Can a wave be caused by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cannon A waves are caused by atrial contraction against a closed tricuspid valve, such as in complete heart block.

Atrial fibrillation (Option A) causes the absence of waves.

Second-degree heart block (Option B): shows subtle variation and may show a progressive increase in the a-c interval.

Tricuspid regurgitation (Option C): causes fused CV waves.
